message_1: A car manufacturer claims that its new sedan model has an average fuel efficiency of 30 miles per gallon (mpg) with a standard deviation of 2.5 mpg. A sample of 50 sedan cars is taken to test this claim. Calculate the 95% confidence interval for the true mean fuel efficiency of the sedan model based on the sample data.
message_2:
To calculate the 95% confidence interval for the true mean fuel efficiency of the sedan model based on the sample data, we will use the following formula:

Confidence Interval = X̄ ± Z * (σ / √n)

where:
X̄ = sample mean (in this case, the claimed average fuel efficiency of 30 mpg)
Z = Z-score for the desired confidence level (for a 95% confidence interval, Z = 1.96)
σ = population standard deviation (2.5 mpg)
n = sample size (50 sedans)

Confidence Interval = 30 ± 1.96 * (2.5 / √50)

First, calculate the standard error (σ / √n):

Standard Error = 2.5 / √50 ≈ 0.3536

Now, calculate the margin of error (Z * Standard Error):

Margin of Error = 1.96 * 0.3536 ≈ 0.6926

Finally, calculate the confidence interval:

Confidence Interval = 30 ± 0.6926
Lower Limit = 30 - 0.6926 ≈ 29.3074
Upper Limit = 30 + 0.6926 ≈ 30.6926

The 95% confidence interval for the true mean fuel efficiency of the sedan model based on the sample data is approximately (29.3074, 30.6926) mpg.
